articles.headline: Are the Federal Reserve’s Rate Increases Working?
articles.snippet: The Fed’s campaign to slow the economy is gradually taking hold, but officials have been particularly surprised by the job market's resilience.
articles.abstract: The Fed’s campaign to slow the economy is gradually taking hold, but officials have been particularly surprised by the job market's resilience.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve this year has raised interest rates at the fastest pace since the 1980s, making it increasingly expensive to borrow money as it seeks to slow consumer and business demand and drive inflation lower.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Justice Dept. Is Said to Investigate Ticketmaster’s Parent Company
articles.snippet: The inquiry predates the botched presale of Taylor Swift tickets this week and is said to focus on whether Live Nation has abused its power in the live music industry.
articles.abstract: The inquiry predates the botched presale of Taylor Swift tickets this week and is said to focus on whether Live Nation has abused its power in the live music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation into the owner of Ticketmaster, whose sale of Taylor Swift concert tickets descended into chaos this week, said two people with knowledge of the matter. The investigation is focused on whether Live Nation Entertainment has abused its power over the multibillion-dollar live music industry.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Ben Sisario

articles.headline: Garland Names Special Counsel for Trump Inquiries
articles.snippet: Even before Mr. Garland’s announcement, there were signs that prosecutorial activity in both cases was accelerating after a brief slowdown in the run-up to the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: Even before Mr. Garland’s announcement, there were signs that prosecutorial activity in both cases was accelerating after a brief slowdown in the run-up to the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Attorney General Merrick B. Garland appointed a special counsel on Friday to take over two major criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump, examining his role in events leading up to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol and his decision to retain sensitive government documents at his home in Florida.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush, Charlie Savage, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Elon Musk’s Twitter Teeters on the Edge After Another 1,200 Leave
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk sent emails on Friday asking to learn about Twitter’s underlying technology as key infrastructure teams have been decimated.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk sent emails on Friday asking to learn about Twitter’s underlying technology as key infrastructure teams have been decimated.
articles.lead_paragraph: Elon Musk sent a flurry of emails to Twitter employees on Friday morning with a plea.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac, Mike Isaac and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: Elizabeth Holmes Is Sentenced to More Than 11 Years for Fraud
articles.snippet: Ms. Holmes was convicted in January of four counts of fraud for deceiving investors with claims about her blood testing start-up Theranos.
articles.abstract: Ms. Holmes was convicted in January of four counts of fraud for deceiving investors with claims about her blood testing start-up Theranos.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of the failed blood-testing start-up Theranos, was sentenced to more than 11 years in prison on Friday for defrauding investors about her company’s technology and business dealings.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: How Fairfield University Ended Up With Few Low-Income Students
articles.snippet: Fairfield has the lowest percentage of Pell Grant recipients of any college in the United States. But was it a choice?
articles.abstract: Fairfield has the lowest percentage of Pell Grant recipients of any college in the United States. But was it a choice?
articles.lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — Last night, the first official basketball game at Fairfield University’s brand-new, 85,000-square-foot Leo D. Mahoney Arena took place. The building, which cost $51 million, takes pride of place in the center of campus.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber

articles.headline: Former Anti-Abortion Leader Alleges Another Supreme Court Breach
articles.snippet: Years before the leaked draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, a landmark contraception ruling was disclosed, according to a minister who led a secretive effort to influence justices.
articles.abstract: Years before the leaked draft opinion overturning Roe v. Wade, a landmark contraception ruling was disclosed, according to a minister who led a secretive effort to influence justices.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court investigates the extraordinary leak this spring of a draft opinion of the decision overturning Roe v. Wade, a former anti-abortion leader has come forward claiming that another breach occurred in a 2014 landmark case involving contraception and religious rights.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Jo Becker

articles.headline: What Is Next for the FTX Fallout?
articles.snippet: The dramatic collapse of the crypto exchange continues to reverberate throughout the industry.
articles.abstract: The dramatic collapse of the crypto exchange continues to reverberate throughout the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offer a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
articles.byline: By Ephrat Livni

articles.headline: In New Special Counsel, a Prosecutor Schooled in Corruption Cases
articles.snippet: A veteran public corruption and war-crimes prosecutor, Jack Smith will take over two Trump-related criminal investigations.
articles.abstract: A veteran public corruption and war-crimes prosecutor, Jack Smith will take over two Trump-related criminal investigations.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jack Smith was appointed to lead the Justice Department’s public integrity unit in 2010, he recommended closing a series of high-profile investigations into members of Congress without charges — attracting criticism that the division had lost its nerve. He rejected that idea.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer

articles.headline: Kari Lake Claims Her Voters Were Disenfranchised. Her Voters Tell a Different Story.
articles.snippet: Ms. Lake’s supporters say in testimonials that they had problems at Phoenix-area polling sites. But a review by The New York Times shows that most of them successfully cast their ballots.
articles.abstract: Ms. Lake’s supporters say in testimonials that they had problems at Phoenix-area polling sites. But a review by The New York Times shows that most of them successfully cast their ballots.
articles.lead_paragraph: When he stepped inside a Phoenix polling place on the morning of Election Day on the way to work, Kevin Bembry was told that the tabulation machines were not functioning properly and he might want to vote somewhere else.
articles.byline: By Charles Homans, Alexandra Berzon, Jim Rutenberg and Ken Bensinger

articles.headline: How Colleges and Sports-Betting Companies ‘Caesarized’ Campus Life
articles.snippet: In order to reap millions of dollars in fees, universities are partnering with betting companies to introduce their students and sports fans to online gambling.
articles.abstract: In order to reap millions of dollars in fees, universities are partnering with betting companies to introduce their students and sports fans to online gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: In September 2021, an official in Michigan State University’s athletic department sent an email to his boss with exciting news: An online betting company was willing to pay handsomely for the right to promote gambling at the university.
articles.byline: By Anna Betts, Andrew Little, Elizabeth Sander, Alexandra Tremayne-Pengelly and Walt Bogdanich

articles.headline: Desperate for Growth, Aging Casino Company Embraced ‘Degenerate Gambler’
articles.snippet: David Portnoy, who has a history of misogynistic and racist behavior, is now a public spokesman for the sports-betting industry.
articles.abstract: David Portnoy, who has a history of misogynistic and racist behavior, is now a public spokesman for the sports-betting industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: Years before he became a controversy-courting media icon, gambling promoter, liquor pitchman and pizza reviewer, David S. Portnoy was drowning in debts.
articles.byline: By Emily Steel

articles.headline: Why States Were Unprepared for the Sports-Betting Onslaught
articles.snippet: Government oversight of sports betting offers scant consumer protections and looks to the industry to police itself, The Times found.
articles.abstract: Government oversight of sports betting offers scant consumer protections and looks to the industry to police itself, The Times found.
articles.lead_paragraph: David Hummel placed his first sports bet in January 2021, wagering $250 on the underdog in a mixed-martial-arts fight. He won $662.50, he said, “and it was probably the worst thing that could have happened to me.”
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Kenneth P. Vogel and Joe Drape

articles.headline: Cigars, Booze, Money: How a Lobbying Blitz Made Sports Betting Ubiquitous
articles.snippet: The gambling industry and its allies got their way with lawmakers after showering them with donations, gifts and dubious arguments.
articles.abstract: The gambling industry and its allies got their way with lawmakers after showering them with donations, gifts and dubious arguments.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Representative John Barker, a cattle breeder, retired judge and chairman of one of the most powerful committees in the Kansas legislature, had a glass of 30-year Redbreast Irish whiskey in his hand and a Don Tomas cigar from Honduras in his mouth.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: At Least 5 Dead and 25 Injured in Gunman’s Rampage at an L.G.B.T.Q. Club in Colorado
articles.snippet: The police said a suspect in the shooting, who was also injured, was arrested.
articles.abstract: The police said a suspect in the shooting, who was also injured, was arrested.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — A man shrouded in body armor and wielding an AR-15 style rifle attacked an L.G.B.T.Q. nightclub in Colorado Springs on Saturday night, in a rampage that killed at least five people and injured at least 25 others.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Mitch Smith, Adam Goldman and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: A Crowd of Possible Trump Rivals Renews G.O.P. Fears of a Divided Field
articles.snippet: Ron DeSantis, Ted Cruz, Mike Pompeo, Nikki Haley and other Republicans with a potential eye on 2024 gathered in Las Vegas at a moment of deep vulnerability for Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: Ron DeSantis, Ted Cruz, Mike Pompeo, Nikki Haley and other Republicans with a potential eye on 2024 gathered in Las Vegas at a moment of deep vulnerability for Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Ted Cruz aggressively worked one ballroom, taking selfies and staying for handshakes with donors and activists for so long the linens had already been cleared.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher

articles.headline: Club Q Patron Who Tackled Gunman ‘Saved Dozens and Dozens of Lives’
articles.snippet: The carnage at a Colorado Springs nightclub where at least five people were killed in a shooting on Saturday night could have been far worse, the club’s owners said.
articles.abstract: The carnage at a Colorado Springs nightclub where at least five people were killed in a shooting on Saturday night could have been far worse, the club’s owners said.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The patron who tackled a gunman inside a gay nightclub in Colorado Springs on Saturday night prevented a deadly shooting from being far worse, the club’s owners said on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Charlie Brennan

articles.headline: How Do You Pronounce Qatar? Probably Incorrectly.
articles.snippet: Is it Kuh-TAR, like guitar? Or KUH-ter, like cutter? A vital World Cup investigation.
articles.abstract: Is it Kuh-TAR, like guitar? Or KUH-ter, like cutter? A vital World Cup investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it Kuh-TAR, like guitar? Or KUH-ter, like cutter? A vital World Cup investigation.
articles.byline: By Sarah Lyall

articles.headline: Inside a Crypto Nemesis’ Campaign to Rein In the Industry
articles.snippet: Gary Gensler, the chair of the S.E.C., is at the center of a reckoning over the future of cryptocurrency after the implosion of FTX.
articles.abstract: Gary Gensler, the chair of the S.E.C., is at the center of a reckoning over the future of cryptocurrency after the implosion of FTX.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March, eight months before his cryptocurrency empire imploded, Sam Bankman-Fried joined a video call with Gary Gensler, a longtime financial regulator who now leads the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany

articles.headline: Can Big Tech Get Bigger? Microsoft Presses Governments to Say Yes.
articles.snippet: Microsoft’s $69 billion deal for Activision Blizzard, which is undergoing reviews in 16 countries, has become a test for whether tech giants can buy companies amid a backlash.
articles.abstract: Microsoft’s $69 billion deal for Activision Blizzard, which is undergoing reviews in 16 countries, has become a test for whether tech giants can buy companies amid a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, Microsoft has accused Sony, its chief video game rival, of misleading regulators. Its lawyers have showed off game consoles, including an Xbox, to British officials. And the president of a major union that Microsoft wooed has spoken up on the company’s behalf to the Federal Trade Commission.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Beyond Meat Is Struggling, and the Plant-Based Meat Industry Worries
articles.snippet: A few years ago, business was booming. That growth has slowed, with some wondering if the number of consumers has reached its limit.
articles.abstract: A few years ago, business was booming. That growth has slowed, with some wondering if the number of consumers has reached its limit.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a while, it seemed Beyond Meat was taking over the world.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell

articles.headline: On the River at Night, Ambushing Russians
articles.snippet: Ukrainian units plying the Dnipro River venture behind enemy lines under the cover of darkness, carrying out reconnaissance and sabotage.
articles.abstract: Ukrainian units plying the Dnipro River venture behind enemy lines under the cover of darkness, carrying out reconnaissance and sabotage.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON THE BANKS OF THE DNIPRO RIVER, Ukraine — Under cover of darkness, a group of soldiers heaved their dinghy off the sand into the water. Another group loaded equipment with a heavy clanking into their boat, while a third pushed off silently with oars. Engines humming quietly, the boats turned to the open water and disappeared into the blackness.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: ‘He Saved a Lot of Lives’: Combat Veteran Tackled Colorado Gunman
articles.snippet: The quick actions of a retired army major and others took down the gunman before he reached a crowded patio.
articles.abstract: The quick actions of a retired army major and others took down the gunman before he reached a crowded patio.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — Richard M. Fierro was at a table in Club Q with his wife, daughter and friends on Saturday, watching a drag show, when the sudden flash of gunfire ripped across the nightclub. His instincts from four combat deployments as an Army officer in Iraq and Afghanistan kicked in.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps, Jack Healy, Shawn Hubler and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Key Freight Rail Union Rejects Deal, Increasing Strike Risk
articles.snippet: The tentative agreement, brokered in September with help from the Biden administration, had averted a strike before the midterm elections.
articles.abstract: The tentative agreement, brokered in September with help from the Biden administration, had averted a strike before the midterm elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of a union that primarily represents freight rail conductors have narrowly voted down a tentative labor contract, their union said Monday.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber
